Line 55: Line 55:
In 1980, the Goodyear Airdock was designated a [[List of historic civil engineering landmarks|Historic Civil Engineering Landmark]] by the [[American Society of Civil Engineers]].
In 1980, the Goodyear Airdock was designated a [[List of historic civil engineering landmarks|Historic Civil Engineering Landmark]] by the [[American Society of Civil Engineers]].
  +
[[Image:Goodyear Airdock interior.jpg|thumb|left|Interior of the Goodyear Airdock, May 1985]]
The Airdock has more recently served as the site of the 1986 kickoff rally for the [[United Way of America|United Way]] of [[Summit County, Ohio|Summit County]], where 200,000 members of the public visited. [[Bill Clinton]] spoke during his [[United States presidential election, 1992|1992 election campaign]], bringing some 30,000 visitors to the site.
The Airdock has more recently served as the site of the 1986 kickoff rally for the [[United Way of America|United Way]] of [[Summit County, Ohio|Summit County]], where 200,000 members of the public visited. [[Bill Clinton]] spoke during his [[United States presidential election, 1992|1992 election campaign]], bringing some 30,000 visitors to the site.
In 1987, the [[Loral Corporation]] purchased Goodyear Aerospace and the Goodyear Airdock as a result of [[James Goldsmith]]'s [[greenmail]]ing of Goodyear. The Loral Corporation (and its holdings, such as the Goodyear Airdock) was purchased by [[Lockheed Martin]] in 1996. The Airdock is not open to the public, but it can be seen by those traveling on [[U.S. Route 224]] east of downtown Akron.
In 1987, the [[Loral Corporation]] purchased Goodyear Aerospace and the Goodyear Airdock as a result of [[James Goldsmith]]'s [[greenmail]]ing of Goodyear. The Loral Corporation (and its holdings, such as the Goodyear Airdock) was purchased by [[Lockheed Martin]] in 1996. The Airdock is not open to the public, but it can be seen by those traveling on [[U.S. Route 224]] east of downtown Akron.
